page.title: 06SHEEP REARING N-E LEICS
page.content: {SHEEP The basis of livestock rearing here is usually a flock of ewes, the number of which will often remain constant from ,with losses due to old age, lambing, and infertility, being made up from the ewe lambs produced by the flock. The flock must be{"dipped"}twice a year against sheep scab etc.A police officer must be present at the dip. {Lambing}takes place in early spring, with the ewes kept in the open until a week or two before lambing starts.The lambs are reared on the farm until the autumn when they will be sent to the {market,}usually at Melton Mowbray for meat.The farmer receives a subsidy from the govt. to top up the market price A supplementary income is gained in early June when the ewes are{sheared.}The main breeds here are Masham, Border-Leicester and Suffolks.
